Title: Information Security in a Multi-User Computer Environment
Abstract: The problem of “computer security” ranges from physical protection of computer equipment to the physical and logical protection of computer-based data. As the techniques of physical security are well known and simple to apply, this chapter stresses on the problems and prospects for protecting data or information in multi-user computer environments. The emphasis is on the threats inherent in programming and using a system rather than various forms of internal and external penetration of the “smash-and-grab” variety, or the subversion of employees having legitimate access to a system. Not discussed at any length are the topics of administrative controls, physical security techniques, personnel screening, and many other aspects of security that are required in greater or lesser degree to devise a secure system. One is often confronted with the question: Is it possible to build a completely secure system? The answer must be unqualifiedly negative. However, it is possible to build an adequately secure system for a particular operational environment. The chapter shows that there is no single set of measures that can be taken to obtain “instant security.” Information security is a problem of providing sufficient barriers and controls to force a prospective penetrator into attacks that carry a high risk of detection and/or have a very large work factor. The work factor, if high enough, will be sufficient to deter all but the most dedicated penetrator, and for him it may make any eventual success a hollow victory. © 1972, Academic Press Inc.

Title: Security advances in banking systems
Abstract: In retail and international banking, there is a growing demand for upto-date information. Security is an important factor in all aspects of bank work. © 1985.
Author Keywords: banking; computer networks; data processing

Author full names: Wood, Charles Cresson (57210508279); Zeidler, Howard M. (7101647420)
Title: Security modules: Potent information security system components
Abstract: In the future, the security of computer and data communications systems will to a large extent depend on the secure handling of secret parameters. Such parameters include log-on passwords, Personal Identification Numbers(PINs), encryption keys, encryption Initialization Vectors (IVs), pseudo-random number-generator quantities, and biometric personal identification quantities like digitized fingerprints. The greater dependency on such security parameters will be the natural outgrowth of both the increasing sophistication and the increasing computerization of security functions. A new approach to protected storage and protected processing of security parameters is the use of a special type of hardware/firmware-based equipment variously referred to as security modules, tamper-resistant modules, and cryptographic security modules. This paper describes representative functions that security modules perform, the benefits to be derived when security modules are deployed, and some current and future applications of this new technology. © 1986.
Author Keywords: cryptographic security module; Security module; tamper-resistant module
Index Keywords: CRYPTOGRAPHY; SECURE STORAGE; SECURITY MODULE; SOFTWARE PROTECTION; TAMPER-RESISTANT MODULE; DATA PROCESSING

Authors: McEvers J.A.; Krichinsky A.M.; Layman L.R.; Dunnigan T.H.; Tuft R.M.; Murray W.P.
Title: IMPLEMENTATION OF THE FACILITY-INTEGRATED COMPUTER SYSTEM (FICS) FOR NUCLEAR MATERIAL ACCOUNTABILITY.
Abstract: A computer system that has been developed for nuclear material accountability and has been operating in an active radiochemical processing plant involving remote operations is described. The FICS was developed (1) to provide improved nuclear material accountability and control and (2) to provide information security. The system has become part of ORNL's Engineering Safeguard Program which has the objective of demonstrating process monitoring as it might be accomplished by inspectors of a nuclear fuel recycle facility.
Index Keywords: Chemical plants; Computers; RADIOCHEMISTRY; Nuclear fuels

Authors: Tyra Neil W.; Miles Paul A.
Title: SYSTEMATIC METHOD FOR EVALUATING SECURITY REQUIREMENTS COMPLIANCE.
Abstract: The authors introduce the security compliance analysis model (SCAM) as a tool for evaluating the degree of security requirement satisfaction. The model provides a means for compiling independently derived compliance evaluations over the broad spectrum of security issues: COMSEC, OPSEC, TEMPEST and Red/Black, ADPE security, physical security, information security, industrial security, and system security areas. The model relates these broad security issues to their constituent parameters (partitioning, shielding, isolation, separation, etc. ) via a hierarchical tree structure. Also provided is a means for assigning relational weighting factors that signify the parameter's relative significance to the overall security category. Finally, the model interprets compliance factors and proceeds through a mathematical algorithm to generate a series of scoring values that may be graphed over time.
Index Keywords: MILITARY COMMUNICATIONS - Space Applications; MILITARY ENGINEERING - Electronic Countermeasures; COMMAND AND CONTROL SYSTEMS; DATA SECURITY; DATA PROCESSING

Author full names: Reitman, Richard P. (6602632313); Andrews, Gregory R. (7202160811)
Title: Certifying information flow properties of programs: An axiomatic approach
Abstract: Interesting program properties other than functional correctness can be addressed and proved using axiomatic logic. An information flow logic that defines the flow semantics of a parallel programming language is presented. Proofs in this logic can be used to certify programs with respect to information security policies. The flow logic can also be combined with correctness logics to form an even more powerful deductive system. © 1979 ACM.

Abstract: Information Security is not only a technical, professional topic but also a societal issue. As such, it can be discussed as an important element of the International Information Flow debate and related to many of the issues raised in this debate. It has also become an issue in its own right. The international business community is involved in the discussions and has a clear position on the IIF issues in general as well as on the Information Security issue.

Abstract: Seven information security issues are addressed: the information explosion; the conflict between a free society and information security; defining sensitive information; industry concerns versus governmental concerns; the market for security technology; the cost of such technology; and the drivers behind expanded application of information security in the sensitive, but unclassified, community of users.

Title: MECHANISM FOR INFORMATION CONTROL IN PARALLEL SYSTEMS.
Abstract: P. J. Denning and D. E. Denning have shown how the information security of sequential programs can be certified by a compile-time mechanism. This paper extends their work by presenting a mechanism for certifying parallel programs. The mechanism is shown to be consistent with an axiomatic description of information transmission.
Index Keywords: Data processing

Title: Security in electronic data processing; [SICHERHEIT IN DER EDV. ERFAHRUNGSBERICHT EINES LANGJAHRIGEN EDV ANWENDERS]
Abstract: Making electronic data safe involves the securing of data processing machines against mistakes, destruction or misuse, and of the data against destruction, falsification and access by unauthorized persons. It comprises the total sum of of all technical, constructional, program technical and organisational measures against mistakes and destruction of the processing machines, against mistakes and abuses during information processing as well as against destruction, loss or falsification of the information. Security measures are therefore required against human error, against defects in the processing machines, against fire, water and explosions as well as against actions by unauthorized persons (destruction, falsification, eradication, unauthorized access to information). Damage usually leads to material or financial loss.
Index Keywords: computer; computer analysis; information system; professional secrecy

Authors: Andreassen A.L.; Leighton W.J., III; Schreiber D.F.

Title: Information Security: An Overview
Abstract: Information security technology encompasses all measures used to protect information from unauthorized disclosure, modification, or destruction. In an age when information is widely recognized as a valuable commodity, information security has become particularly vital. This issue of the AT&T Technical Journal brings together papers on various aspects of digital electronic information security, representing work in many areas of the company. This paper presents a brief overview of the problems addressed by information security technology and how its focus has changed with the advance of computing science. © 1988 AT&T Technical Journal
Index Keywords: CRYPTOGRAPHY; ACCESS PROTECTION; INFORMATION SECURITY; SECURE SYSTEMS; SECURITY TECHNOLOGY; SYSTEM V/MLS; DATA PROCESSING

Title: The impact of overclassification on personnel and information security
Abstract: Unnecessary and unwarranted classification adversely affects both information and personnel security systems in a variety of ways. This study explores the range of possible repercussions and identifies the findings and recommendations of major examinations of these systems over the past thirty years. Although consensus exists that Overclassification poses problems for information and personnel security, wide disagreement is evident over the perceived centrality and seriousness of Overclassification, its principal causes, and its remedies. Nowhere are these differences more manifest than in the assumptions, conclusions, and recommendations emerging from the Reagan Administration and Congress in 1985. © 1986.

Title: GENERAL ELECTRIC: AN APPROACH TO DISASTER RECOVERY.
Abstract: Business dependency on information systems deepens many executives' concerns about protecting their information resources against intrusion and disaster. In diversified companies, it is easy to cite differences in products and information processing systems as justification for making each profit center carry full operational and investment responsibility for its own disaster recovery. At General Electric, commonalities in both facilities and equipment lead to an approach which conserved investments and vitalized each profit-center's recovery plan. A company-wide 'disaster prevention service' has emerged, and it includes a 'disaster recovery facility'. It does not prevent nature's disasters; it does keep them from becoming disasters to profit-center performance. Disaster prevention is one part of the company-wide Information Security and Control Program.
Index Keywords: DATA PROCESSING, BUSINESS - Fire Protection; COMPUTER SECURITY; DISASTER RECOVERY; GENERAL ELECTRIC COMPANY; INFORMATION SECURITY; COMPUTER SYSTEMS, DIGITAL

Title: A context for information systems security planning
Abstract: Management is often rightfully dissatisfied with the performance of many information security efforts. After investment of considerable resources, and prolonged waiting for results, many efforts can demonstrate little if any significant improvement. This is largely due to a lack of planning. Many efforta lack explicitly articulated plans as well as specific performance milestones. Although many are loathe to admit it, information security efforts at many organizations lack formal planning and performance monitoring. Management's dissatisfaction with information security is exemplified by the seriously inadequate staffing levels found at a large number of organizations. When management is convinced that information security is a prudent investment, they will respond with additional resources. This article examines why information security efforts are often ineffective and why more formal planning efforts can alleviate this condition. It discusses tools best used to prepare an action plan for information security and gives some tips on how to sell such a plan to management. Also discussed are organizational design, policies, standards, and guidelines and other elements of a foundation that is required if an effective information security planning process is to be sustained. The article dwells on the establishment of a context for effective information security planning. © 1988.
Author Keywords: Cost effectiveness; Goal setting; Information security; Performance monitoring; Project planning; Risk analysis; Systems security

Title: DEVELOPMENT OF AN URBAN CATV AMPLIFIER.
Abstract: Due to the large transmission capacity of CATV which gives it a wide range of potential uses, a number of facilities other than those for only simultaneous retransmission of television broadcasts are coming into existence. These facilities are used for independent broadcasting of local information, security, and automatic meter reading. In addition, a number of plans to build two-way urban CATV systems in Japan's major cities have been proposed and are attracting much interest as a significant development in today's media devices. Designed for use in urban CATV, a highly functional, compact, lightweight 350/450 MHz amplifier has been developed. The system and its reliability have been evaluated and it has been determined that it has sufficient practical applicability. The results are reported.
Index Keywords: AMPLIFIERS, VIDEO; URBAN PLANNING - Japan; CATV AMPLIFIER; HIGH-RISE BUILDINGS; TRUNK AND BRIDGING AMPLIFIER; URBAN CENTERS; TELEVISION SYSTEMS, CABLE

Authors: Clark David D.; Wilson David R.
Author full names: Clark, David D. (55613235535); Wilson, David R. (57198541648)
Title: COMPARISON OF COMMERCIAL AND MILITARY COMPUTER SECURITY POLICIES.
Abstract: The authors present a policy for data integrity based on commercial data processing practices, and compare the mechanisms needed for this policy with the mechanisms needed to enforce the lattice model for information security. It is argued that a lattice model is not sufficient to characterize integrity policies, and that distinct mechanisms are needed to control disclosure and to provide integrity.
Index Keywords: COMPUTERS - Applications; COMMERCIAL COMPUTER SECURITY; COMPUTER SECURITY; MILITARY COMPUTER SECURITY; DATA PROCESSING

Title: Security issues in the telecommunications industry
Abstract: Information security is a growing concern for both industry and Government. Until a few years ago, security-related losses in industry were primarily due to disgruntled or misled employees. More recently, hackers from the outside without special access authorizations have gained the spotlight as they use various public and private networks to gain corporate intelligence, transfer free services to friends, or disrupt data processing activities. The weaknesses exploited in many of the more recent hacker cases represent a combination of naive system design and lax administration. Security measures must address both information system design and information policy administration.
Index Keywords: Computer Crime; Industrial Management; Telecommunication

Title: HOW TO CONTROL MVS USER SUPERVISOR CALLS.
Abstract: Many computing centres install their own extensions to standard operating systems. These extensions, when processed in an authorized status, may seriously endanger system integrity. This paper, based on case studies over the past five years, spells out the risks run by computing centres under multiple virtual storage (MVS) installing home-grown user SuperVisor Calls. A set of design requirements is formulated with which these user SVCs must comply if they are to be considered secure. The latest developments in improving the security of some risky operations also are outlined.
Index Keywords: SECURITY SYSTEMS - Computer Applications; DESIGN REQUIREMENTS; INFORMATION SECURITY; MVS USER SUPERVISOR CALLS; SYSTEM CONTROLLABILITY; DATA PROCESSING

Title: From tangled webs to network integrity: computer security in hospital management. Part II.
Abstract: This article is the second of two on the subject of computer security in hospital management in the first part, the authors dramatized the need for not only information security awareness but also the need for implementation of security measures to protect valuable information. This second article provides an overview of the components of a good computer security plan, contains a brief explanation of some of the new network security technology available today, and gives the reader several sources that can provide further information on information security.

Title: NEW LOCKS AND KEYS FOR ELECTRONIC INFORMATION.
Abstract: This report examines US federal government policies directed at protecting information, particularly in electronic communications systems. It examines the vulnerability of communications and computer systems and the trends in technology for safeguarding information in these systems. The discussion covers government activities, policy alternatives, and technical standards.

Title: HUMAN FACTOR CONTROLS FOR INFORMATION SECURITY.
Abstract: Information security will be successful only when the people constrained by security controls accept the need for security and support it. Technical controls that safeguard assets by technical means, such as password access control, frequently reduce performance and are resisted unless the people required to use them are willing to cooperate. Human controls, that is, the personnel procedures or requirements for safeguarding assets and technical controls, also condition and constrain people to accept security controls and to cooperate in making them effective.
Index Keywords: COMPUTER SECURITY; HUMAN FACTORS; SECURITY CONTROLS; DATA PROCESSING

Title: THREE-TIERED APPROACH TO MICROCOMPUTER SECURITY.
Abstract: Security measures are as important to microcomputer systems as to any other major investment. Procedures should cover three areas: physical security, information security, and disaster recovery. This article discusses these three areas, along with microcomputer system basics, security threats, and other aspects of the subject.
Index Keywords: COMPUTER OPERATING SYSTEMS - Security Systems; COMPUTER SOFTWARE - Security Systems; COMPUTERS, MICROCOMPUTER

Title: MANY FACES OF DATA VULNERABILITY.
Abstract: Information is a major commodity: computer security to protect that information has recently been receiving great attention in the public press. However, neither the value of information nor the necessity for its security are new issues. The advent of the computer and telecommunications has not introduced new issues so much as transformed the nature of old ones. Historically, paper money and hard currency have been sequestered in steel and concrete vaults, with combination locks on the doors. Later, money was transferred via paper checks that were processed manually. Today, most money is stored in electronic form inside computer systems, which are the new vaults. So the current focus is on making computer systems more secure to protect electronic money as well as sensitive information. The article discusses the need for new security methods and problems involved in enforcement.

Title: PRAGMATIC APPROACH TO INFORMATION RESOURCES SECURITY.
Abstract: A technique for reviewing the security status of information resources within an organization has been developed and introduced. It provides a broad view of different aspects of data security, can be carried out quickly, and offers a practical approach to security problems.
Index Keywords: DATA PROCESSING - Security of Data; FUNCTIONAL SECURITY; INFORMATION SECURITY; PHYSICAL SECURITY; QUALITY SECURITY; INFORMATION SERVICES

Title: Information security: Reality and fiction
Abstract: Awareness of the need for true information security is steadily evolving in finance, industry and government, although action does not match rhetoric. There is a growing need for sophisticated security measures as evidenced by the increasing incidence of penetrations, at all levels of sophistication, of automated systems. These security measures can be developed and installed based on a procedure of risk analysis, security audit and design of countermeasure. © 1984.

Index Keywords: TELECOMMUNICATION SYSTEMS; COMPUTER FRAUD; INFORMATION SECURITY; DATA PROCESSING

Title: Distributed processing systems security: Communications, computer, or both
Abstract: Information security involves many components, including communication security, computer security, physical security, and personnel security. This paper deals only with communication and computer security. In systems that involve either communications systems or monolithic computer systems (but not both) the overall requirements for information security are relatively straightforward, or at least relatively well understood. However, in distributed processing systems that usually involve both communications and computer components, there is a need for both communications as well as computer security techniques. This paper addresses communications security, computer security, and their relationship in information protection in the distributed processing environment. © 1986 IEEE.

Title: INFORMATION SECURITY AND NETWORK PROTOCOLS.
Abstract: After a brief review of the concepts of data security in computer systems, the ″consistency″ problem is introduced and its historical background given. It is then discussed how the consistency problem fits with existing computer security information flow models and propose a modification to model consistency. The requirements for a democratic processing network are found to be well-described by this model. Finally, a technique for implementing the required function in a network is given, and its impact on network protocol design is assessed.
Index Keywords: DATA PROCESSING - Security of Data; Computer networks

Title: Changing missions, technologies, & cultural shock in telemetry and communications
Abstract: Local area networks which handle many signals in addition to real-time process information are becoming increasingly common. These systems are characterized by longer control loops, often going many thousands of feet to a central processing unit for control and logging. The construction, maintenance, and reliability problems which long lines create have frequently been solved by routine telephone technology which can be transferred to the process industries. Gateways which access outside systems are also frequently present. Network information security and protection from electrical harm are additional problems that outside interconnections introduce. The local network border is usually a demarcation not only of ownership and responsibility, but also of hardware, craft, nomenclature, and corporate cultural and political differences. Both the public communications net and private process control systems can benefit from understanding of what each can bring to their integrated services.
Index Keywords: Computer Systems, Digital - Real Time Operation; Data Processing - Security of Data; Data Transmission - Security Systems; Microprocessor Chips - Applications; Telecommunication Equipment; Long Control Loop Reliability; Network Information Security; Private Process Control Systems; Public Communication Networks; Real Time Information Processing; Telemetry; Computer Networks

Title: Security issues in the telecommunications industry
Abstract: Information security is a growing concern for both industry and Government. Until a few years ago, security-related losses in industry were primarily due to disgruntled or misled employees. Although computers and networks might have been involved, the unhappy, misled, or careless employee operating from the inside with the benefit of privileged access was the usual perpetrator of damages or embezzlement. More recently, hackers from the outside without special access authorizations have gained the spotlight as they use various public and private networks to gain corporate intelligence, transfer free services to friends, or disrupt data processing activities. Illustrative of the importance of security in the Government sector is the example of a case of electronic eavesdropping that affected East-West negotiations and subsequently the price of wheat and bread in this country. The weaknesses exploited in many of the more recent hacker cases represent a combination of naive system design and lax administration. It is pointed out that security measures must address both information system design and information policy administration.
Index Keywords: Data Processing--Security of Data; Corporate Intelligence; Electronic Eavesdropping; Hackers; Information Security; Private Networks; Service Availability; Telecommunication

Authors: Saydjari O.Sami; Beckman Joseph M.; Leaman Jeffrey R.
Author full names: Saydjari, O.Sami (56628144200); Beckman, Joseph M. (7101978964); Leaman, Jeffrey R. (6602420506)
Title: LOCK trek: navigating uncharted space
Abstract: The design principles of the Logical Coprocessing Kernel (LOCK) project are considered. LOCK is an advanced development of hardware-based computer security and cryptographic service modules. Much of the design and some of the implementation specifications are complete. The Formal Top Level Specification (FTLS) also is complete and the advanced noninterference proofs are beginning. This hardware-based approach has brought the LOCK project into many uncharted areas in the design, verification, and evaluation of an integrated information security system. System integration currently appears to be the single largest programatic problem. The authors examine two important design areas: design verification and porting Unix System V to a LOCK host. The verification tools seem able to verify design only and not implementation.
Index Keywords: Computer Hardware; Computer Metatheory--Formal Logic; Computer Operating Systems; Computer Operating Systems UNIX; Cryptographic Service Modules; Formal Top Level Specification; Hardware-Based Computer Security; Integrated Information Security System; Logical Coprocessing Kernel; Data Processing

Authors: Walter K.G.; Schaen S.I.; Ogden W.F.; Rounds W.C.; Shumway D.G.; Schaeffer D.D.; Biba K.J.; Bradshaw F.T.; Ames S.R.; Gilligan J.M.
Title: Structured specification of a security kernel
Abstract: Certifying an entire operating system to be reliable is too large a task to be practicable. Instead, we are designing a Security Kernel which will provide information security. The kernel's job is to monitor information flow in order to prevent compromise of security. Sound design is encouraged by using a technique called Structured Specification, in which successively more detailed models of the Security Kernel are developed. The initial model, M0, is an abstract description which formalizes governmental security applied to computer systems. Subsequent levels of modeling provide increasingly more detail, and gradually the models begin to resemble a particular system (Multics in this case). The second model, M1, defines a tree-structured file system, and an interagent communication system while M2 adds details concerning segmentation in a dynamic environment. It is intended that the final level of modeling will specify the primitive commands for the kernel of a Multics-like system and will enumerate precisely those assertions which must be proved about the implementation in order to establish correctness. © 1975, ACM. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Compromise security; Governmental security; Model; Security kernel; Security system; Structured programming; Structured specification

Title: DETERRENCE THROUGH INFORMATION SHARING.
Abstract: Problems associated with intrusion and theft of valuable information associated with telephony, computer networks and modern electronics are discussed. Means for the prevention of such problems are dealt with. The roles of government agencies, legislatures, security consultants and the use of a 'friendly bulletin board' are dealt with.

Title: A survey of issues in computer network security
Abstract: Computer networks are proliferating rapidly for a number of reasons discussed in this paper. During this boom, relatively little attention has been paid to computer network security. This paper describes problems posed by network security and presents a survey of methods and technologies available today to enhance network security. Current methods are discussed, including information security strategy, computer security and its relation to network security, data communications security, and data encryption. Ideas from promising areas of research close the paper. © 1986.

Title: Planning: A means to achieve data communications security
Abstract: To remain competitive, and to achieve our goals, we must refine our approaches to strategic planning and incorporate them into management activities. One important refinement of strategic planning involves the preparation and maintenance of an information security plan to help resolve a serious problem (exemplified by the "tragedy of the commons") found in data communications and multi-user computer environments. This article addresses the factors compelling us to be more serious about planning such as the increasing amplitude and frequency of technological change. It discusses ways of using a plan to create an appropriate information systems security environment. These include using a plan to generate a sense of urgency about information security, and using a plan as the foundation for engineering a conversation with management about appropriate security measures. The article considers the specific problems encountered when information security planning is inadequate and proposes that a target secure computing environment be defined as the starting point of an information security plan. Ways of incorporating flexibility into a security plan are also described. 25 specific examples of data communications controls are provided to assist readers in developing control measures suitable for inclusion in their own information security plans. © 1989.

Title: DYNAMIC SIGNATURES FOR PERSONAL IDENTITY VERIFICATION.
Abstract: Present demands for greater information security require accuracy in personal identity verification, as well as speed, ease of use, and reliability. Devices employing biometric measurement of individually unique features or personal activities are now being developed and marketed. The author describes one such product, Securisign, which is designed to accurately, rapidly, and reliably verify personal identity with an economical, user-friendly device which relies on the unique characteristics of an individual's dynamic signature. An additional advantage is that Securisign can prevent access of people under the influence of alcohol or drugs.
Index Keywords: CONTROL SYSTEMS; INFORMATION RETRIEVAL SYSTEMS; BIOMETRIC MEASUREMENTS; DYNAMIC SIGNATURES; PERSONAL IDENTITY VERIFICATION; SECURITY SYSTEMS

Title: SOME PROBLEMS ARISING OUT OF THE CROSS-DISCIPLINARY NATURE OF INFORMATION SYSTEMS SECURITY.
Abstract: It is suggested that risk management departments in companies are the appropriate location for the information security risk manager (ISRM) position with its professional standards. An empirical survey was conducted to support a proposed theory that the three academic majors (risk management, auditing, and information systems) can pursue the ISRM career path on almost equal footing, but found an apparent interdisciplinary gap. An interdisciplinary university-level course in managing information systems security is thus proposed. Also suggested is the establishment of a data and knowledge base for information security risk management, to develop expert systems in a way that would fully incorporate current diverse efforts, modify or correct the past efforts, and point out future directions.
Index Keywords: ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE; DATABASE SYSTEMS; RISK STUDIES; CROSS-DISCIPLINARY NATURE; EMPIRICAL SURVEY; INFORMATION SYSTEMS SECURITY; KNOWLEDGE BASE; RISK MANAGEMENT DEPARTMENTS; MANAGEMENT

Title: Information systems security: Management success factors
Abstract: Even if an organization has the best technical computer security talent and the most dedicated staff, it may still have an ineffective systems security function. This situation is frequently encountered and is caused by too much emphasis on the technical aspects and too little attention to the managerial aspects of systems security. Many of us in the systems security field immerse ourselves in fascinating technical details at the expense of the managerial issues essential to the success of a systems security effort. This article-discusses the managerial perspectives with which an appropriate balance between the managerial and the technical may be struck. Although each organization has its idiosyncrasies, experience has shown that a number of common approaches to managing an information systems security function are both effective and prudent. While there exists no standard template with which one can design a systems security function, this article illuminates some tried-and-true methods associated with organizational design, raising the level of management awareness, and obtaining needed resources. This article is based partly on a panel discussion for which the author was the moderator, an informal poll of San Francisco bay area systems security administrators and EDP auditors, and the author's information systems security consulting experience. © 1987.
Author Keywords: Awareness raising; Budgeting; Chain of command; EDP auditing; Information security; Information systems security; Internal communications; Internal politics; Internal security functions; Interpersonal relations; Management style; Obtaining cooperation; Organizational structure; Personal factors; Reporting relationships; Staffing; Systems security
Index Keywords: MANAGEMENT - Information Systems; INFORMATION SECURITY; INTERNAL SECURITY FUNCTIONS; ORGANIZATIONAL STRUCTURE; DATABASE SYSTEMS

Title: Operations security: The missing link
Abstract: Operations security (OPSEC) is described as a rational approach to identifying and protecting information that adversaries could otherwise exploit to the detriment of an agency or corporation. A theoretical analysis of an aspect of OPSEC, namely, how to measure its effectiveness in the context of defining it and placing responsibility for its effectiveness, is presented. The analysis is based on a systems approach. Procedures for implementing this approach are given.
Index Keywords: Data Processing--Security of Data; Management--Information Systems; Risk Studies--Assessment; Technology--Protection; Information Security; Operations Security; Security Management; Technology Security; Security Systems

Author full names: Swangim, JoAnn (6506175495); Strauss, Jack L. (57203070853); Kolkmeier, Thomas J. (6504530138); Acevedo, Teresa (6507728070); Friedman, Art (57198779699)
Title: Challenges of tomorrow - The future of secure avionics
Abstract: The authors identify INFOSEC (information security) challenges specific to advanced avionics in military systems and present a methodology for addressing these challenges. This methodology is based on a system engineering approach to integration of security with the advanced avionics. The authors also discuss the trusted computing base (TCB) as an emerging INFOSEC technology for providing security services in an A3 (advanced avionics architecture). The application of existing COMPUSEC (computer security) guidelines, specifically the the National Computer Security Center (NCSC) Rainbow Series, is discussed in the context of an advanced avionics environment.
Index Keywords: Aircraft, Military; Data Processing--Security of Data; Advanced Avionics; Secure Avionics; Security Services; Trusted Computing Base; Avionics

Title: CRYPTOGRAPHY ARCHITECTURE FOR INFORMATION SECURITY.
Abstract: Information being transferred from point to point over a public communications carrier or stored on portable media can be protected, by the use of cryptography, from accidental or intentional disclosure. Control functions are required to ensure synchronization of the process. In a communications environment, the control functions become logically part of the network architecture. IBM's Systems Network Architecture (SNA) has been extended to allow the use of cryptography when sensitive information is being processed. Architectural similarities for the file environment are discussed.
Index Keywords: Computer networks; Data processing

Title: Information security issues in an APL application
Abstract: This paper will describe various methods to secure an APL database application. Primary foci will be in the areas of "physical" protection, and in cryptographic techniques. To that end, distinctions will be made between "data," and "information.' Because of those differences, specific methods will bs offered which are appropriate for each modality of security. A brief set of examples will be included for the use of IBM1s1 RACF2 (Resource Access Control Facility). Also, a description of a Public Key Cryptographic function, implemented in APL, will be offered. Finally, these will be combined into a database scenario, applicable to products like APLDI2∗ (APL Data Interface). © 1984 ACM.
Index Keywords: Access control; Cryptographic functions; Cryptographic techniques; Data interfaces; Database applications; Public keys; Resource access control; Cryptography

Title: Cardiology office computer use: Primer, pointers, pitfalls
Abstract: An office computer is a utility, like an automobile, with benefits and costs that are both direct and hidden and potential for disaster. For the cardiologist or cardiovascular surgeon, the increasing power and decreasing costs of computer hardware and the availability of software make use of an office computer system an increasingly attractive possibility. Management of office business functions is common; handling and scientific analysis of practice medical information are less common. The cardiologist can also access national medical information systems for literature searches and for interactive further education. Selection and testing of programs and the entire computer system before purchase of computer hardware will reduce the chances of disappointment or serious problems. Personnel pretraining and planning for office information flow and medical information security are necessary. Some cardiologists design their own office systems, buy hardware and software as needed, write programs for themselves and carry out the implementation themselves. For most cardiologists, the better course will be to take advantage of the professional experience of expert advisors. This article provides a starting point from which the practicing cardiologist can approach considering, specifying or implementing an office computer system for business functions and for scientific analysis of practice results. © 1986, American College of Cardiology Foundation. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: cardiology; computer; computer analysis; heart; priority journal

Title: COMPUTER SECURITY AND THE END-USER.
Abstract: Today's information system is a tightly knit partnership of people, machines and communications facilities bound together by software and procedures and policies. The relationships will differ from system to system but the fundamental ingredients and dependencies are the same. The information system of the future will place even greater stress on the people side of this partnership with profound information security implications.
Index Keywords: COMPUTER SECURITY; END-USERS; INFORMATION SYSTEMS; DATA PROCESSING

Title: SECURITY FOR SECURITY AGAINST COMPUTER INTRUSION.
Abstract: Confidentiality is a requirement that we face during our everyday work in information security. This topic of the security of security has never received sufficient attention in the information security field and is now more important because of the outsider computer intrusion problems caused by hackers. The purpose of this paper is to make a significant impression and motivate the information security practitioner. The broad issues of this topic will be presented followed by specific recommendations for security of security.
Index Keywords: SECURITY SYSTEMS - Computer Applications; COMPUTER INTRUSION; COMPUTER SECURITY; CONFIDENTIALITY AGREEMENTS; SENSITIVE SECURITY INFORMATION; COMPUTER SYSTEMS, DIGITAL

Title: DYNAMIC ANALYSIS OF THE EFFECTS ACCESS RULE MODIFICATIONS HAVE UPON SECURITY.
Abstract: A technique is presented for analyzing the relationships among the predicates in a predicate-based security model for database management systems. The principal tool of the technique is the Boolean difference, which is used to examine the relationships among the predicates when users are allowed to be members of more than one user group. The effects of deleting or adding predicates on the user group definition are identified by the technique. The technique is most valuable to information security authorizers who define and maintain access-control rules.
Index Keywords: Database systems; ACCESS CONTROL; ACCESS RULE MODIFICATIONS; Data processing

Title: Bar coding and identification of the patient; [LE CODE A BARRES ET L'IDENTIFICATION DES HOSPITALISES]
Abstract: The use of a bar-coding technique for patient identification has been developed at the Brest Regional hospital center. Separate paragraphs discuss the different requirements of the nursing wards, medical technical and logistic services and hospital data processing service. The benefits of this system for the nursing wards and other services are listed; emphasis is placed on easy management, patient information security and economy of the system.
Index Keywords: computer analysis; France; information processing; medical record; methodology; nonhuman; organization and management; patient coding; patient information; short survey

Title: How security fits in - a management view. Security is an essential for quality information
Abstract: Today's businesses require quality information; that is, business operations management requires that information have qualities of reliability, integrity, and privacy. This fact makes selling the need for computer security easier, since security is one of the necessary elements for ensuring information quality. This report explains how quality information concepts were used as a basis for a presentation to the senior management people of a large business. © 1974.
Author Keywords: Computer security; Information management; Information quality; Information security; Security management
Index Keywords: DATA PROCESSING - Security of Data; COMPUTER SECURITY; INFORMATION MANAGEMENT; INFORMATION SECURITY; SECURITY MANAGEMENT; MANAGEMENT

Authors: Zheng Y.; Matsumoto T.; Imai H.
Author full names: Zheng, Yuliang (7404837201); Matsumoto, Tsutomu (7407963117); Imai, Hideki (56894680100)
Title: On the construction of block ciphers provably secure and not relying on any unproved hypotheses
Abstract: One of the ultimate goals of cryptography researchers is to construct a (secrete-key) block cipher which has the following ideal properties: (1) The cipher is provably secure, (2) Security of the cipher does not depend on any unproved hypotheses, (3) The cipher can be easily implemented with current technology, and (4) All design criteria for the cipher are made public. It is currently unclear whether or not there really exists such an ideal block cipher. So to meet the requirements of practical applications, the best thing we can do is to construct a block cipher such that it approximates the ideal one as closely as possible. In this paper, we make a significant step in this direction. In particular, we construct several block ciphers each of which has the above mentioned properties (2), (3) and (4) as well as the following one: (1’) Security of the cipher is supported by convincing evidence. Our construction builds upon profound mathematical bases for information security recently established in a series of excellent papers. © Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg 1990.
Index Keywords: Lyapunov methods; Security of data; Block ciphers; Current technology; Design criteria; Mathematical basis; Provably secure; Cryptography

Title: Principles and procedures of the LRAM approach to information systems risk analysis and management
Abstract: Risk assessment methods vary in nature and depth. Their application to the evaluation of information security issues should be decided on the basis of their capability to provide answers to the fundamental questions concerning the design and implementation of security controls in specific information systems. Information systems risk analysis is discussed as a means of providing an objectively based approach for assessing and managing risk. As a decision making and risk assessment tool, rigorous risk analysis is not only capable of identifying potential losses that could be unacceptable for a given system, but it can be used to determine which specific security controls and counter measures can be effective and justifiable by management-set criteria. The Livermore Risk Analysis Methodology (LRAM) was developed in accord with these principles. Its model and procedures, from the identification of valuable assets to the prioritization and budgeting of proposed controls, are examined and discussed both from the technical and from the decision making/risk management perspectives. © 1987.
Author Keywords: Cost-benefit ratio; Information systems security; Loss potential indicator; Maximum potential loss; Qualitative risk analysis; Quantitative risk analysis; Risk management

Title: CAUSE-AND-EFFECT MODEL FOR PERSONAL COMPUTERS.
Abstract: The cause-and-effect model described here is a problem definition tool. It can be used as an organizer of 'brainstorm' ideas and proposed solutions developed by several people. It can achieve consensus and group commitment to an agreed upon and focused problem solution attack in line with corporate goals and objectives. We believe it is suitable as a tool for selling and teaching information security for personal computers.
Index Keywords: DATA PROCESSING - Security of Data; INFORMATION SECURITY; COMPUTERS, PERSONAL

Title: A position paper on computing and communications
Abstract: The effective operation of free enterprise in creating the envisioned information service industry is dependent on three accomplishments: 1. The restructuring of our information processing industry to provide a clear separation among costs for computing, communications, and the development of information services. 2. The wide use of multi-access system concepts so that information services may share in the use of computer installations, and so their cost of construction is reasonable. 3. The development of public, message-switched communications services with adaquate provisions for information security. © 1967 Association for Computing Machinery Inc. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Security of data; Information service industries; Multi-access systems; Position papers; Switched communications; Information services

Title: COMPUTER SECURITY: A GLOBAL CHALLENGE, PROCEEDINGS OF THE SECOND IFIP INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON COMPUTER SECURITY, IFIP/SEC'84.
Abstract: This conference proceedings consists of 48 papers. The main subjects are digital signatures in banking, computer security, encryption, computer security and productivity, computer systems access control, operating systems security, database security, EDP auditing, risk analysis, contingency planning, computer crime, communications and network security, office information security, personal computer security, and data protection.

Title: Cryptosystems based on an analog of heat flow
Abstract: It is commonplace to base computer security and information security on hard problems. Recent cryptosystems have been based on the knapsack problem [DE83, pp. 118-126; BRS5] and the problem of factoring an integer [DE83, pp. 104-1091. The former problem is N P complete [GA79, p. 2471. The place of the latter problem in complexity theory is not well understood, but it has been around in number theory for a long time. © Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg 1988.
Index Keywords: Combinatorial optimization; Number theory; Security of data; Complexity theory; Hard problems; Knapsack problems; P-complete; Cryptography

Title: PROTECTING YOUR INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY.
Abstract: Protecting intellectual property is a design function. It is also an engineering and business necessity. Every engineer in design work, particularly those in technical lead and management positions, should be aware of this aspect of the design profession. Every design organization should have a program to avoid infringements and protect the creations of its staff by appropriate documentation, state-of-the-art studies, patenting, and information security. This paper reviews the ground rules for establishing such a program and recommends the procedures to be followed. A review of the elements of the United States patent law and the available facilities of the Patent and Trademark Office is also given.
Index Keywords: ENGINEERING - Record Preservation; Patents and inventions

Author full names: Adam, Nabil R. (7006657317); Worthmann, John C. (57190041471)
Title: Security-control methods for statistical databases: A comparative study
Abstract: This paper considers the problem of providing security to statistical databases against disclosure of confidential information. Security-control methods suggested in the literature are classified into four general approaches: conceptual, query restriction, data perturbation, and output perturbation. Criteria for evaluating the performance of the various security-control methods are identified. Security-control methods that are based on each of the four approaches are discussed, together with their performance with respect to the identified evaluation criteria. A detailed comparative analysis of the most promising methods for protecting dynamic-online statistical databases is also presented. To date no single security-control method prevents both exact and partial disclosures. There are, however, a few perturbation-based methods that prevent exact disclosure and enable the database administrator to exercise “statistical disclosure control.” Some of these methods, however introduce bias into query responses or suffer from the 0/1 query-set-size problem (i.e., partial disclosure is possible in case of null query set or a query set of size 1). We recommend directing future research efforts toward developing new methods that prevent exact disclosure and provide statistical-disclosure control, while at the same time do not suffer from the bias problem and the 0/1 query-set-size problem. Furthermore, efforts directed toward developing a bias-correction mechanism and solving the general problem of small query-set-size would help salvage a few of the current perturbation-based methods. © 1989, ACM. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Compromise; controls; disclosure; inference; security
Index Keywords: Data Processing--Security of Data; Database Security; Statistical Databases; Database Systems

Author full names: Barker, L. Kirk (57196548360); Nelson, Larry D. (7402251100)
Title: Security Standards—Government and Commercial
Abstract: Computer security standards are needed to reduce the cost of security products and to allow for interoperability and evaluation. Several national and international groups are trying to standardize approaches to information security for certain applications. This paper describes and compares three types of standards activities: United States government standards, financial standards, and standards developed for the International Standards Organization Open Systems Interconnection Basic Reference Model. © 1988 AT&T Technical Journal
Index Keywords: STANDARDS; COMPUTER SECURITY STANDARDS; FINANCIAL STANDARDS; GOVERNMENT STANDARDS; INFORMATION SECURITY; SECURITY STANDARDS; DATA PROCESSING

Title: European needs and attitudes towards information security
Abstract: The needs for security of information (in computer systems, on telecommunications and on media) are rather uniform throughout Western Europe, and are seen as being significantly different from the needs in the United States. Recognition of these needs is, however, quite varied; attitudes towards the best methods for satisfying the needs are even more varied.The situation with respect to these needs and attitudes is described for the major countries of Western Europe. The official and unofficial attitudes towards policy and regulation of information security technology (particularly cryptology) is also described for these countries. In particular, it is clear that, with a very few exceptions, neither official nor unofficial policy level organizations are prepared to follow the position advocated by the U.S. Government in such matters. © 1988 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.
Author Keywords: Information security; Proprietary algorithms; Regulation

Title: Protecting ownership of proprietary information
Abstract: This article presents an effective approach to the use and protection of intellectual property (a catch-all term for patents, trademarks, copyrights and trade secrets) in a manner that will prevent most losses. It will also provide direction for preventing the use of proprietary information by others who may do so in a manner that may be contrary to law, trade practices and agreements. © 1989.
Author Keywords: Copyright; Encryption; Information policy; Information security; Intellectual property; Patent; Trade secret

Abstract: [No abstract available]
Index Keywords: COMPUTERS; DATA COMMUNICATION NETWORKS; INFORMATION SECURITY; LOGICAL SECURITY; MULTINATIONAL COMPANIES; PHYSICAL SECURITY; DATA PROCESSING, BUSINESS

Authors: Blom Rolf; Forchheimer Robert; Fak Viiveke; Ingemarsson Ingemar
Author full names: Blom, Rolf (7005825037); Forchheimer, Robert (6603934747); Fak, Viiveke (6602931694); Ingemarsson, Ingemar (7005573461)
Title: ENCRYPTION METHODS IN DATA NETWORKS.
Abstract: Data transmitted in a data network with several users are subject to unintended processing or distribution by mistake or by unauthorized tampering. The data convey information which may be disclosed to an unauthorized user, destroyed and thus not recoverable or modified. Information security is the degree to which the information is protected against accidental or intentional destruction, disclosure, or modification. One of the most efficient methods to achieve information security is to encrypt the data carrying the information. By the use of encryption the information is effectively protected against unintended disclosure. Destruction or modification is detected by verification, using methods similar to encryption. In this paper it is shown how encryption may be used in data networks with a view to making the reader aware of existing methods and conveying some knowledge of how to make efficient use of encryption.
Index Keywords: DATA PROCESSING - Security of Data; Data transmission; DATA NETWORKS; ENCRYPTION; Computer networks

Title: Organizational structuring of the computer security function
Abstract: The effectiveness of an organizational unit can be dramatically affected in a positive or negative way by its placement within the organization. Because protection of the information resource is becoming more and more critical for organizational survival, the organizational positioning of computer security is being investigated in this study. According to data gathered from 39 U.S. organizations with data or computer security administrators, the function is currently being relegated to lower levels in the organizational hierarchy. Security officers are most frequently being supervised by line managers in the IS (Information Systems) area. There are exceptions to this pattern, notably in financial institutions and government, but overall evolutionary trends of security unit initiation do not typically include high level reporting relationships. From the standpoint of the need for independent watchguards, this policy is unwise. A normative model for organizational placement of the security function is offered as a solution to the present state of affairs. Use of this prescriptive model should greatly assist IS and top corporate managers in administering the information security area. © 1988.
Author Keywords: Hierarchical placement of computer security; Organizational structuring of EDP audit; Organizational structuring of security; Principle of control independence
Index Keywords: MANAGEMENT; COMPUTER SECURITY; EDP AUDIT; ORGANIZATIONAL STRUCTURING OF SECURITY; DATA PROCESSING

Title: PROBLEMS OF ORGANIZING A NETWORK OF AUTOMATED IMAGE-PROCESSING SYSTEMS.
Abstract: The need for creating a network of automated image-processing systems (AIPS) is substantiated. A structure of a multilevel network is proposed and substantiated. The principal requirements on the hardware and software and on the information assurance of each level of an AIPS network are formulated.
Index Keywords: AIPS; AUTOMATED IMAGE PROCESSING SYSTEM; DATA LINKS; REGIONAL AUTOMATED IMAGE PROCESSING CENTERS; IMAGE PROCESSING

Title: Executive coordination and oversight of security classification administration
Abstract: Despite its critical importance to the nation, the information security or security classification system under every presidential administration since World War II has been subjected to criticism about its scope and purpose. In the past few years, the tension between access to government information and the protection of national security has increased. Today, the Information Security Oversight Office serves to help ease that tension. Through various oversight initiatives, it strives to limit the extraordinary protection of national security classification to only that very sensitive information that merits such shelter. © 1984.

Title: Skytrain high technology rapid transit in Vancouver
Abstract: B.C. Transit opened North America's most advanced rapid transit system in 1986. The 23 km line uses lightweight aluminum vehicles with steerable axle trucks propelled by linear motors. The operating concept is equally innovative with driverless trains and self-service ticketing at unmanned stations. Roving staff provide information, security, ticket inspection and system supervision. The system has been highly successful in its 3 1/2 years of operation, carrying 90 million passengers safely with high reliability. Ridership has reached projections and extensive development around stations has demonstrated the economic benefits of the system. This paper describes the system planning, system technology, including initial problems with noise and vibration, and system operation. Capital costs, method of funding and economic return are described. © Copyright 1989 Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: Light rail transit; Light weight vehicles; Linear motors; Aluminum vehicles; Economic benefits; Economic returns; High reliability; Noise and vibration; Operating concept; Rapid transit systems; System operation; Rapid transit

Title: The background of executive order 12356
Abstract: This explanation of the development of E.O. 12356 originally appeared as an appendix to Annual Report to the President FY 1982 (Washington, D.C., 1983) by the Information Security Oversight Office, U.S. General Services Administration, Washington, D.C. 20405. © 1984.

Title: SECURITY IMPLICATIONS OF THE SPACE STATION INFORMATION SYSTEM.
Abstract: The author addresses various aspects of the space station information system (SSIS) and the implications each has on the information security issues from a systems point of view. Security areas addressed include: physical, personnel, computer hardware, computer software, procedure, COMSEC, emanations, and education. State-of-the-art hardware concepts for both secure voice and commercial COMSEC are presented. A brief description of the Space Station Program is given. A descriptive overview of the SSIS along with the data types that various customers will use is also included.
Index Keywords: DIGITAL COMMUNICATION SYSTEMS - Space Applications; SPACE PLATFORMS; INFORMATION SECURITY; SPACE STATION INFORMATON SYSTEM; DATA PROCESSING

Title: LOGGING, SECURITY EXPERTS DATA BASE, AND CRYPTO KEY MANAGEMENT.
Abstract: This paper presents three important - and likely to soon to be available - facilities that will help increase the security associated with computer systems of the 1990s. They are, in the order of their presentation, (1) enhanced logging and monitoring facilities, (2) an on-line database of information security experts, and (3) generalized encryption key management packages. These facilities are described from a functional rather than an implementation standpoint. The basis for stating that these facilities will soon be available is simply the author's last six years of research and consulting experience in the computer security field at SRI International and the Bank of America.
Index Keywords: Cryptography; Database systems; CRYPTO KEY MANAGEMENT; LOGGING FACILITIES; SECURITY EXPERTS; Data processing

Title: Identity-based conference key distribution systems in broadcast networks
Abstract: Identity-based conference key distribution systems in a complete graph network or a star network are proposed. Messages among two or more users are authenticated using each user's identification information. Security and transmission efficiency for the proposed schemes are also shown. © 1987, The Institution of Electrical Engineers. All rights reserved.

Title: WHAT ABOUT YOUR LEGAL PARACHUTE WHEN YOUR DATA SECURITY CRASHES?
Abstract: 'There is no data security - only some possibilities to protect your information. ' This is how the author starts his speech about computer and information security in the organization. The author discusses the possible opportunities for organizations to find out how vulnerable their information processing activities has become. The main subjects are mailbox systems security, privacy protection, and data protection legislation.
Index Keywords: COMPUTER SYSTEMS, DIGITAL - Protection; LEGISLATION; COMPUTER SECURITY; DATA PROCESSING, BUSINESS

Title: Evolving key technologies in IT systems
Abstract: The ultimate information technology system will provide the user with a language-free, natural-human-interface capability to store, retrieve, manipulate and communicate information. Key technologies in its achievement will include computing and storage, speech recognition, artificial intelligence, database technology, protocols, information security and language translation.
Index Keywords: Artificial Intelligence; Data Processing; Database Systems; Information Science--Language Translation and Linguistics; Speech--Recognition; Information Security; Natural-Human-Interface; Information Retrieval Systems

Authors: Walter K.G.; Schaen S.I.; Ogden W.F.; Rounds W.C.; Shumway D.G.; Schaeffer D.D.; Biba K.J.; Bradshaw F.T.; Ames S.R.; Gilligan J.M.
Title: STRUCTURED SPECIFICATION OF A SECURITY KERNEL.
Abstract: Certifying an entire operating system to be reliable is too large a task to be practicable. The authors describe the designing of a Security Kernel which provides information security. The kernel's job is to monitor information flow in order to prevent compromise of security. Sound design is encouraged by using a technique called Structured Specification, in which successively more detailed models of the Security Kernel are developed.
Index Keywords: COMPUTER OPERATING SYSTEMS - Mathematical Models; COMPUTER PROGRAMMING - Structured Programming; Data processing

Title: MAKING INFORMATION SYSTEMS MORE SECURE.
Abstract: The author discusses an Information Security Management Awareness Program currently being developed. This program is intended to be simple, be suitable for different types of organizations, have risk assessment (without halo effect above), result in economically sound project selection, and be an on-going program with security-circles, awards, and individual objectives stated in job descriptions.
Index Keywords: INFORMATION SECURITY; INFORMATION SECURITY RISKS; INFORMATION SYSTEMS; DATA PROCESSING

Title: Changing missions, technologies, & cultural shock in telemetry and communications
Abstract: Local area networks which handle many signals in addition to real-time process information are becoming increasingly common. These systems are characterized by longer control loops, often going many thousands of feet to a central processing unit for control and logging. The construction, maintenance, and reliability problems which long lines create have frequently been solved by routine telephone technology which can be transferred to the process industries. Gateways which access outside systems are also frequently present. Network information security and protection from electrical harm are additional problems that outside interconnections introduce. The local network border is usually a demarcation not only of ownership and responsibility, but also of hardware, craft, nomenclature, and corporate cultural and political differences. Both the public communications net and private process control systems can benefit from understanding of what each can bring to their integrated services.
Index Keywords: Process Control; Telemetering Systems; Telephone Systems; Central Processing Unit; Gateways; Integrated Services; Local Area Networks; Private Process Control Systems; Public Communications Net; Computer Networks

Title: MANAGEMENT INFORMATION & DECISION SUPPORT (MIDS) SYSTEM AT THE LOCKHEED-GEORGIA COMPANY.
Abstract: The Lockheed-Georgia Company's MIDS System is a very successful management tool to provide the president and his staff with information essential to monitor the company's performance and support their decision making. System concepts and system software were produced inhouse to satisfy the following basic requirements; ease of use; quick location of needed information; security; accuracy; ease of display creation; timely updates of displays. The present MIDS System team consists of members of the Management Information and Control Services Department (Finance Organization) and the User Support Department (Information Services Organization).
Index Keywords: AIRCRAFT MANUFACTURE - Management; DATA PROCESSING - Security of Data; INFORMATION RETRIEVAL SYSTEMS; DECISION SUPPORT SYSTEMS; PERFORMANCE MONITORING; MANAGEMENT

Title: Identity-Based Information Security Management System for Personal Computer Networks
Abstract: This paper proposes an information security management system in a network, which authenticates and/or encrypts a message. Both authentication and key distribution are executed in a simple scheme. Once the system is set up, the transactions are done independently by the users involved, and there is no need for centers. Nevertheless, the information for users to keep is small. This paper describes the experimental implementation of the proposed system on a personal computer network, using IC cards (smart cards) and digital signal processors. Digital signal processors shorten calculation time and make it practical. © 1989 IEEE
Index Keywords: Computer Networks; Computers, Personal; Cryptography; Electronic Mail; Signal Processing--Digital Techniques; IC Cards (Smart Cards); Identity Based Authentication; Information Security Management System; Key Distribution System; Personal Computer Networks; Data Processing

Author full names: Andrews, Gregory R. (7202160811); Reitman, Richard P. (6602632313)
Title: An Axiomatic Approach to Information Flow in Programs
Abstract: A new approach to information flow in sequential and parallel programs is presented. Flow proof rules that capture the information flow semantics of a variety of statements are given and used to construct program flow proofs. The method is illustrated by examples. The applications of flow proofs to certifying information flow policies and to solving the confinement problem are considered. It is also shown that flow rules and correctness rules can be combined to form an even more powerful proof system. © 1980, ACM. All rights reserved.

Title: Information security in integrated avionic systems
Abstract: Integrated avionic systems are being developed for application in the majority of future military aircraft. In these applications, the current technique of integrating and maintaining information security (INFOSEC) by using discrete electronic systems and wiring is no longer adequate. The author defines the areas of concern and provides direction for determining the requirements to maintain INFOSEC within the integrated avionic system. He concludes that INFOSEC in integrated avionic systems requires a coherent set of operational/system security policies and trusted computing base designs supported by communication security (COMSEC) and TEMPEST techniques. This coherence prevents costly overkill and inadequate designs. Full time INFOSEC engineering from each INFOSEC technology must be included in the avionic system design from the beginning.

Authors: Ingemarsson I.; Tang D.T.; Wong C.K.
Author full names: Ingemarsson, Ingemar (7005573461); Tang, Donald T. (56296285500); Wong, C.K. (7404954450)
Title: A Conference Key Distribution System
Abstract: Encryption is used in a communication system to safeguard information in the transmitted messages from anyone other than the intended receiver(s). To perform the encryption and decryption the transmitter and receiver(s) ought to have matching encryption and decryption keys. A clever way to generate these keys is to use the public key distribution system invented by Diffie and Hellman. That system, however, admits only one pair of communication stations to share a particular pair of encryption and decryption keys. The public key distribution system is generalized to a conference key distribution system (CKDS) which admits any group of stations to share the same encryption and decryption keys. The analysis reveals two important aspects of any conference key distribution system. One is the multitap resistance, which is a measure of the information security in the communication system. The other is the separation of the problem into two parts: the choice of a suitable symmetric function of the private keys and the choice of a suitable one-way mapping thereof. We have also shown how to use CKDS in connection with public key ciphers and an authorization scheme. © 1982. IEEE. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: ENCRYPTION; DATA TRANSMISSION

Title: Data media/communication - Security and recovery
Abstract: The security problems attendant upon the growth of the electronic office are discussed. The potentially disastrous consequences of ignoring security problems is emphasized, and the point is made that data security costs are much less than the costs of recreating data in the event of a total loss. A security concept based on backup data housed in a data safety chamber is espoused.

Title: Electronic information security in a digital environment
Abstract: The protection of sensitive, unclassified industrial information is considered. Context and background are described, and the objects and objectives of security processes are discussed. Common descriptors of data protection and information security applicable to the security of digital information, which the author entitles electronic information security (ELINFOSEC), are suggested. ELINFOSEC is the adequate protection of information processed in an automated system along with the processing system's assets. The automated system operates as a collection of electronic and optical hardware, software, and firmware configured to collect, create, communicate, compute, disseminate, process, store, or control data and information.

Title: SECURITY CONSIDERATIONS IN THE MICROCOMPUTER ENVIRONMENT.
Abstract: The special characteristics of a small information system complicate the problem of control to an even greater degree than the introduction of automation to the accounting process and to the operational process. These problems can be solved by applying and modifying traditional security and control procedures and by developing new procedures. In order for this to occur, management must fully understand the impact an uncontrolled information system can have on the business. The microcomputer has proven itself in the business environment, and without question will continue to be a driving factor in the way information systems are designed and used. User organizations will probably continue to gain more freedom and control in meeting their own information needs, but they cannot be allowed to do so without some guidance and supervision from a security conscious management.

Title: Floppy diskette security measures
Abstract: Information security - a broader term than computer security - encompasses the safeguarding of information wherever it resides and whatever form it takes. Information security accordingly includes consideration of information residing in file cabinets, voice communications networks, and other places outside computers. It additionally includes consideration of information typewritten on paper, in diagrams, and in other forms that may not be computer controlled. Floppy diskettes are, in many people's eyes, outside the computer security area, and accordingly frequently ignored. Nonetheless, these diskettes often contain sensitive and/or critical information. This paper discusses practical policies, procedures, and technical controls that can be used to appropriately safeguard information resident on floppy diskettes. © 1985.

Title: Enhancing information security with the information resource management approach
Abstract: Recently, computer security and incidents of computer crime have received considerable attention. Without a doubt, in computer security the risks are high, and the problems and their solutions are complex; nonetheless, the emphasis of this attention has been misplaced. The emphasis should be primarily on the security of information itself and secondarily on the devices that handle information and on any of the other factors that go into information production. The factors of information production should certainly be considered, but only after planning and analysis based on information has been completed. For example, when considering the possibility that a competitor may steal your firm's proprietary information, it is best to consider first what information should be safequarded and what expenditure is warranted for such protection; then one can consider the environments in which this information appears (paper-based, computerized, verbal, etc.) and controls that are appropriate for these environments. This paper explores the application to the information security area of Information Resource Management (IRM), a new and promising approach that concentrates, on information not on computers. This paper explains the concepts underlying IRM, how they are applied, and what general information systems benefits can be obtained. In a more specifically security-oriented sense, it indicates how IRM can help address a few of the pressing problems now encountered by information security practitioners: controls suboptimization, the Maginot Line syndrome, top management understanding and support, disaster recovery planning, security policy-making, consideration of noncomputerized information, and expeditious resolution of security problems. © 1983.

Title: Structured specification of a security kernel
Abstract: Certifying an entire operating system to be reliable is too large a task to be practicable. Instead, we are designing a Security Kernel which will provide information security. The kernel's job is to monitor information flow in order to prevent compromise of security. Sound design is encouraged by using a technique called Structured Specification, in which successively more detailed models of the Security Kernel are developed. The initial model, M0, is an abstract description which formalizes governmental security applied to computer systems. Subsequent levels of modeling provide increasingly more detail, and gradually the models begin to resemble a particular system (Multics in this case). The second model, M1, defines a treestructured file system, and an -interagent communication system while M2 adds details concerning segmentation in a dynamic environment. It is intended that the final level of modeling will specify the primitive commands for the kernel of a Multics-like system and will enumerate precisely those assertions which must be proved about the implementation in order to establish correctness. © 1975 Author.

Title: Taking fax security seriously
Abstract: It's not uncommon when security specialists get together for someone to conduct an impromptu poll on such burning issues as single sign-on, client/server security, multiplatform security, data sharing, dial-up security, and downsizing. If the concerns of my security consulting clients are any indicator, these issues certainly belong there. Important as these topics are, however, I want to raise a subject that seldom makes that list but should: the physical and procedural security of fax devices. The issue of fax security isn't difficult to understand or to explain to others. The problem can be presented to business executives with ample justification for concern—and real solutions that require a relatively small investment can be proposed. All in all, it's an attractive combination of problem and solution that doesn't come around often in the field of information security. © 1993 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Abstract: Summary form only given. Title: Parallel implementation of the rsa public-key cryptosystem
Abstract: In just over ten years, public-key crytography has gone from a novel concept to a mainstay of cryptographic technology. Most public-key cryptosystems are constructed based on a modular exponentiation and each modular exponentiation, in turn, is made up of modular multiplications. Title: Physician-hospital networks
Abstract: Patient care efficiencies and quality of care improvements require progressive efforts to integrate the patient information systems and allow for on-demand accessibility to authorized information users.
